awd_titl_txt: Elliptic Curves, p-adic Deformations, and Iwasawa Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
A central problem in number theory is understanding the (integer, or rational) solutions to polynomial equations with integer coefficients. Elliptic curves are a class of such equations that has been studied since antiquity, yet for which many questions still remain open. Elliptic curves are a central object of study in this research. Since the fundamental work of Gross-Zagier and Kolyvagin, powerful tools from algebraic geometry and representation theory have guided research in this direction. The PI aims to leverage some recent developments in those areas to further our understanding of the arithmetic of elliptic curves and related problems.

More specifically, the research is divided into two related parts. The projects in the first part focus on the construction of linearly independent Selmer classes for higher rank elliptic curves. Darmon and Rotger have proposed very precise conjectures in the rank 2 setting, and these projects are expected to yield new results in this direction. The second part focuses on problems in Iwasawa theory, with applications towards the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture, a non-vanishing conjecture by Greenberg in the case of root number -1, and the conjectured local indecomposability of the Galois representations associated to ordinary non-CM forms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this grant was focused on the understanding of the arithmetic of elliptic curves - a special class of polynomial equations with connections to fundamental open problems, such as the congruent number problem and the cube sum problem, going back to antiquity - and generalizations. A motivating problem is the conjecture of Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer, as vastly generalized by the Bloch-Kato conjecture and the main conjectures in Iwasawa theory, which predict a close link between the solutions to polynomial equations of this type and special values of associated analytic functions of a complex variable.

More concretely, the research supported by this project led to significant advances in the following problems:

1) Iwasawa theory of elliptic curves at Eisenstein primes, resulting in the first general proof of Mazur's main conjecture from 1972, and the first proof of Kolyvagins's conjecture from 1991, for such primes p. Applications include new results on the p-part of the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer formula in analytic ranks 0 and 1.

2) The Darmon-Rotger conjecture on the nonvanishing of generalized Kato classes attached to rational elliptic curves of rank 2. The two papers on the topic produced during this award, establishing this conjecture from 2016 in the so-called adjoint CM case, represent some of the very few significant advances on the arithmetic of elliptic curves of rank bigger than 1.

3) The construction of new anticyclotomic Euler systems in three new settings: for the Rankin-Selberg convolutions of two modular forms, for the adjoint representation attached to a modular form, and for a modular forms base-changed to an imaginary quadratic field. By the general theory of Euler systems (in a form recently developed by Jetchev-Nekovar-Skinner) these new constructions yield progress on the Bloch-Kato conjecture in ranks 0 and 1 and the corresponding Iwasawa main conjectures.

Other contributions obtained during this award, but not originally planned before the start of the grant, include:

4) New results on the p-part of the Tamagawa number conjecture (a refined form of the Bloch-Kato conjecture) for higher weight modular forms with complex multiplication in analytic rank 1.

5) New results on the p-part of the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer formula for elliptic curves at multiplicative primes p.

6) A theory of bi-ordinary modular forms, with applications to an outstanding questions by Coleman and Greenberg from the late 1990s on the p-local indecomposability of the Galois representations attached to p-ordinary forms.

During the period of this grant the PI directed five PhD students, whose research activitives (such as participation in the Arizona Winter School) were supported in part by this grant.
